Text_TrustPhys:
Doctors are human. They are people, with limitations, biases, strengths, and weaknesses just like everyone else. That's why I'm skeptical of placing too much trust in any of them. They are seldom as good or as bad as they seem. 

But I distrust my own doctors a lot, as I've gotten older I realize that I have very little in common or agreement with them on many topics. I think that the vast majority of humans are poorly equipped to make sound life decisions, and that includes doctors.   

So I guess I don't even know what it would mean to fully trust a doctor.  I definitely have had periods of time when I didn't trust MY doctors, but it was always in the context of knowing that I had to make certain concessions to access the healthcare system. I knew that I what I thought was in my best interest wasn't always accessible or feasible.  

I know that I complained a lot about my doctors 5 or so years ago. Over time I changed doctors a few times, and while I recognized differences I ultimately can also recognize that I am primarily responsible for making healthcare work for me.

Text_Numeracy: Once I had a friend who long ago got hit in the knee a few times and developed bursitis. She used to have big problems with it and had to frequently visit the doctor. Through her experience and my research I learned that bursitis is inflammation of the bursa (a tiny sac of fluid that reduces friction between two surfaces). The common reason for bursitis is repetitive motion. Treatment often includes RICE (rest, ice, compress, elevate). This simple and straightforward method was enough to keep my friend's knee relatively pain free for several years. Eventually, she had to have surgery on that knee for separation of her meniscus and her doctor drained the bursa and injected an anti-inflammatory. The bursa has not been a problem since.

Text_Numeracy: A living will  is a document that addresses your desires relating to medical treatment in the event you are still alive but unable to express your wishes. Because urgent health care decisions must be made quickly and often the parties involved in making these decisions are not in possession of your desires relating to such treatment, it may be helpful to have two copies of your living will. One copy should be in a place where it can be accessed quickly if needed and one copy can be kept with a trusted family or friends as a back up.

Text_Numeracy: When I was 64, I experienced severe chest pain and shortness of breath while gardening. Recognizing these symptoms as potential signs of a heart attack, I immediately called 911 and was rushed to the hospital. Tests confirmed that I had a blocked artery, and I underwent emergency angioplasty to restore blood flow. This experience reinforced the importance of recognizing the warning signs of medical emergencies and seeking prompt treatment.
Text_Anxiety: Oh, where do I begin? Well, when I visit the doctor's office, I always get anxious about receiving bad news regarding my health. I worry about potential illnesses or conditions that might be discovered during the check-up. Also, just the general uncertainty of not knowing what the doctor will say or recommend can make me feel on edge. And of course, there's always that fear of needles and medical procedures that tend to make me quite anxious as well.
Text_TrustPhys: I trust my primary care physician because they have always taken the time to listen to my concerns and provide thorough explanations of any medical issues. They have shown empathy and a genuine interest in my well-being, which has helped me feel comfortable and confident in their care. Overall, I have built a strong level of trust with my primary care physician based on our positive interactions and successful outcomes.
